title: 109_s3559
content: The Act may be cited as the "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005". It addresses fraud in connection with major disaster or emergency benefits. The "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" amends Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code by adding a section on fraud in connection with major disaster or emergency benefits. It outlines penalties for falsifying information or making fraudulent statements related to disaster relief benefits or procurement of property or services in connection with a disaster declaration. The "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" imposes penalties for fraud related to disaster relief benefits or procurement of property/services in connection with a disaster declaration. Violators can be fined, imprisoned for up to 30 years, or both. The act applies to benefits affecting interstate or foreign commerce, transported through the mail, or involving US government records or payments. The "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" imposes penalties for fraud related to disaster relief benefits or procurement of property/services in connection with a disaster declaration. The act defines "benefit" as any record, voucher, payment, money, or thing of value provided by the government. SEC. 3 and SEC. 4 of the "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" increase criminal penalties for wire, radio, television, and mail fraud related to benefits in connection with a presidentially declared major disaster or emergency. The act also directs the Sentencing Commission. The Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005 directs the United States Sentencing Commission to increase penalties for fraud or theft offenses related to major disaster or emergency declarations. The Commission must submit explanations and policy recommendations to Congress. The Sentencing Commission is required to ensure that sentencing guidelines reflect the seriousness of offenses related to major disasters or emergencies, maintain consistency with other directives, consider aggravating or mitigating circumstances, make necessary changes to guidelines, and align with the purposes of sentencing. The Commission must act promptly to promulgate guidelines or amendments. The Sentencing Commission must ensure that guidelines meet sentencing purposes and act promptly to promulgate guidelines or amendments within 30 days of enactment.
